categories.name: Research Alert
categories.description: Research-heavy updates from journals, labs, and arXiv

items.title: The human exposome could change everything we know about disease
items.rawSummary: Scientists are launching an ambitious global effort to map the â€œhuman exposomeâ€ â€” the lifelong mix of environmental and chemical exposures that drive most diseases. Backed by new partnerships with governments, UNESCO, and international science advisory bodies, the initiative is rapidly expanding across continents. Powered by AI and advanced data tools, the movement seeks to shift medicine beyond genetics and toward the real-world factors shaping human health.

items.rawSummary: ## Search Advanced search ### Quick links Explore articles by subject Find a job Guide to authors Editorial policies Sign up for the Nature Briefing: AI and Robotics newsletter â€” what matters in AI and robotics research, free to your inbox weekly. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript. View all journals Search Log in Content Explore content About the journal Publish with us Sign up for alerts RSS feed Cover runners-up of 2025 Download PDF Download PDF Editorial Published: # Cover runners-up of 2025 Nature Computational Science volume 6, page 111 (2026)Cite this article ### Subjects Computational science Publishing We highlight some of our favorite cover suggestions from 2025. [...] Cover submitted for the paper by Kevin Maik Jablonka and colleagues. Credit: Indrajeet Mandal. Last but not least, an image submitted for the paper by Kevin Maik Jablonka and colleagues is also worth highlighting3."). The figure depicts a luminous wireframe hand â€” which represents artificial intelligence, and more specifically, a vision language models (VLM) â€” writing on a laboratory notebook filled with notes related to chemistry and materials science. Here, the act of writing represents active scientific thinking, interpretation of experimental data, and formation of meaningful conclusions. The paper introduces a benchmark â€” named MaCBench â€” to evaluate whether modern VLMs can truly reason across chemistry and materials science like a scientist, or merely recognize patterns.

items.title: Why You Canâ€™t Say No to Snacks Even When Full
items.rawSummary: By monitoring brainwaves with EEG scans, researchers found that while participants reported being “full” and showed no conscious desire for more food, their brains refused to “devalue” the rewarding sight of snacks. This suggests that food-rich environments can trigger overeating by overriding the bodyâ€™s natural appetite controls. Research from the University of East Anglia (UEA) may finally explain why we still reach for the biscuit tin, even when weâ€™re full. A new study reveals that the human brain continues to respond to tempting food cues even after weâ€™ve eaten enough. In a world of endless adverts and snack cues on every corner, the team say their findings shed light on why so many of us struggle to maintain a healthy weight. ew research reveals that the brain’s reward system ignores satiety signals, continuing to value food cues even when hunger is absent. Credit: Neuroscience News Lead researcher Dr Thomas Sambrook, from UEAâ€™s School of Psychology, said: â€œObesity has become a major worldwide health crisis. But rising obesity isnâ€™t simply about willpower – itâ€™s a sign that our food-rich environments and learned responses to mouth-watering cues are overpowering the bodyâ€™s natural appetite controls. â€œWe wanted to better understand how our brains react to food cues when we are already feeling full. â€œWe studied peopleâ€™s brainwaves after eating and found that even though their stomachs might be satisfied, their brains didnâ€™t seem to care. â€œIn fact, no amount of fullness could switch off the brain’s response to delicious looking food. This suggests that food cues may trigger overeating in the absence of hunger.â€ In the study, 76 volunteers were monitored using Electroencephalogram (EEG) brain scans as they played a rewardâ€‘based learning game with food such as sweets, chocolate, crisps and popcorn. Halfway through the task, participants were given a meal of one of the foods until they didnâ€™t want another bite.

items.title: Study Reveals What Tau PET Scans Are Actually Seeing
items.rawSummary: Study Reveals What Tau PET Scans Are Actually Seeing Featured Neurology Neuroscience · February 28, 2026 Summary: While tau PET scans are vital for “seeing” Alzheimerâ€™s biology in living patients, they have a known quirk: the most common tracer, Flortaucipir (Tauvid), often “lights up” even when tau tangles aren’t the primary driver. In a high-precision study, researchers used AI-enabled, voxel-by-voxel alignment to compare PET scans directly with postmortem brain tissue. They discovered that in non-Alzheimerâ€™s cases and even some controls, the PET signal was actually reacting to iron deposits and MAO-B (a marker of neuroinflammation) rather than tau itself. This “off-target” binding explains why scans can sometimes over-predict the presence of toxic tangles. Tau proteins play an important role in Alzheimerâ€™s disease. Tau helps to stabilize neurons in the brain, but in Alzheimerâ€™s disease, tau proteins can misfold and tangle inside neurons. These tangles spread across the brain forming toxic clumps that impair neuronal function and ultimately lead to cell death. PET scans are one of the few ways that clinicians and researchers can â€œseeâ€ Alzheimerâ€™s disease biology in a living person. PET scans for tau are being increasingly used in specialty clinics and research to estimate the burden and distribution of tau tangles, providing information that can influence diagnostic confidence, prognosis discussions, and how patients are selected for novel Alzheimerâ€™s therapies and tracked in Alzheimerâ€™s drug trials. ?Researchers identified that iron and neuroinflammation can mimic tau pathology on PET scans, providing a roadmap for more accurate diagnostic interpretation. Credit: Neuroscience News At the same time, there is an important limitation to tau PET scans: the most widely used tau PET tracer (Flortaucipir/Tauvid) can also bind to other biological features   in the brain, sometimes showing a low-level signal on scans even when tau is not the main driver of the results. This is especially true in non-Alzheimerâ€™s disorders, where tau protein accumulations show a different structure than in Alzheimerâ€™s disease. In a study appearing February 25 in Acta Neuropathologica , UC San Francisco researchers use a rare combination of patient tau PET imaging plus detailed postmortem brain tissue mapping, to clarify the extent to which non-tau factors influence the Flortaucipir tracer signal. With the aid of AI-enabled, voxel-by-voxel alignment between the PET scan and microscopy, the researchers computationally matched the PET signal to the corresponding tissue location and generated thousands of point-by-point comparisons per person, giving much higher anatomical precision than typical PETâ€“autopsy studies. They then measured, side-by-side, the tissue features most relevant to interpreting flortaucipir: phospho-tau (tau pathology), ferric iron deposits and MAO-B, a marker linked to reactive astrocytes which are a key component of neuroinflammation. They found that in several non-Alzheimerâ€™s tauopathies (and in a non-tau control case), the PET signal was better explained by iron and/or MAO-Bâ€“related processes than by tau itself. â€œOur results help explain  why  tau PET scans sometimes â€˜light upâ€™ beyond what tau pathology alone would predict,â€ says co-senior author Lea T. Grinberg, MD, PhD, a former UCSF neuroscientist and current professor of Neuroscience at the Mayo Clinic .â€œIn Alzheimerâ€™s disease, tau is a major contributor to flortaucipir signalâ€”but not the only one.â€ The researchers believe these findings can help clinicians avoid over-interpretation of borderline signal in a tau PET scan and improve how scans are used for prognosis and trial decisions.

items.title: This AI finds simple rules where humans see only chaos
items.rawSummary: A new AI developed at Duke University can uncover simple, readable rules behind extremely complex systems. It studies how systems evolve over time and reduces thousands of variables into compact equations that still capture real behavior. The method works across physics, engineering, climate science, and biology. Researchers say it could help scientists understand systems where traditional equations are missing or too complicated to write down.

categories.name: Tech Trends
categories.description: Tech & biotech company moves, market changes and funding trends

items.title: Q4 2025 Healthtech VC Trends - PitchBook
items.rawSummary: Activity was especially strong in operations, analytics, and electronic health records, while AI-heavy segments such as clinical documentation, digital care, and provider education attracted outsized capital. The year also saw record VC exit volume, rising IPO momentum led by Omada Health and Hinge Health, and a sharp rebound in PE dealmaking. With AI now central to both clinical and administrative workflows, the data points to continued opportunity across healthtech segmentsâ€”and a healthy pipeline of late-stage companies positioning for exits in 2026. Table of contents [...] Additional Research ### Pharma Biotools VC Trends The Q4 2025 Pharma Biotools VC Trends report provides an analysis of recent VC activity and includes a market map of leading VC-backed companies in the space. ### PitchBook Analyst Note: Tariff Shock: Perspectives on Private Market Impacts This analyst note examines how renewed US tariff uncertainty is reshaping risks, liquidity, and strategy across private credit, PE, VC, and European investments. ### AI Public Comp Sheet and Valuation Guide Our AI Public Comp Sheet and Valuation Guide tracks stock performances, valuations, and market caps of key publicly traded AI companies. February 23rd, 2026 [...] Q4 2025 # Healthtech VC Trends PitchBook clients can access the full report and its Excel data pack via the Research Center on the PitchBook Platform. Healthtech exits hit a record high while AI reshapes investment priorities Healthtech venture funding staged a strong comeback in 2025, with startups raising $15.3 billionâ€”up 26% YoYâ€”as larger deal sizes and AI-driven growth rounds powered the rebound. Fourth-quarter funding dipped slightly from earlier highs but remained more than double the prior-year quarter, underscoring renewed investor confidence. The median pre-money valuation rose to $31 million, reflecting sustained demand for AI-enabled healthcare delivery, operations, and revenue-cycle solutions.

items.title: Brain inspired machines are better at math than expected
items.rawSummary: Neuromorphic computers modeled after the human brain can now solve the complex equations behind physics simulations â€” something once thought possible only with energy-hungry supercomputers. The breakthrough could lead to powerful, low-energy supercomputers while revealing new secrets about how our brains process information.
